observedContent.label: Bars show observed global temperature change

orbital.label: Earth's orbital changes
orbital.title: Is it orbital changes?
orbital.sub: No. Shifts in Earth’s orbit affect climate over thousands of years and longer, not over the time shown here.

solar.label: Solar temperature
solar.title: Is it solar activity?
solar.sub: No. The Sun’s energy output has varied only slightly over the last century, producing almost no impact on recent climate.

volcanic.label: Volcanic activity
volcanic.title: Is it volcanoes?
volcanic.sub: No. Climate records show that large eruptions often cool the planet for several years.

aerosols.label: Aerosols
aerosols.title: Is aerosol pollution?
aerosols.sub: No. Some airborne pollutants reflect solar energy back into space, producing a cooling effect—but these pollutants can also cause smog and acid rain.

ghgs.label: Greenhouse gases
ghgs.title: Is it greenhouse gases?
ghgs.sub: Yes. The rise in heat-trapping greenhouse gases is the only factor that can account for observed warming since 1880.

all.label: All factors
all.title: Human and natural factors
all.sub: Greenhouse gases from human activity are warming the planet. Combined with the slight cooling influence of natural factors, the expected increase temperature closely matches observed warming since 1880.
